snippet: Mary T. Barra, the head of General Motors, called an internal investigation released on Thursday an occasion for the automaker to clean house.
abstract: Mary T Barra, General Motors chief executive, says internal investigation into company's handling of deadly safety defect presented opportunity to clean house, remove incompetent employees and begin anew; many outsiders have opposite reaction, seeing results as fresh ammunition in their continuing struggles with company over compensation to victims and fixes to a regulatory system that allowed defect to go uncorrected for more than a decade.

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and RACHEL ABRAMS
byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald reported from Washington and Rachel Abrams from Detroit.

lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, the head of General Motors, called an internal investigation released on Thursday an occasion for the automaker to clean house.

headline.main: Some See G.M. Report as Powerful Ammunition for Change
